S3.T1.caption: Table 1. Model baselines indicating publication year, venue, and fairness-aware studies that analyzed them.
S3.T1.table:
Models Year Venue Analyzed fairness in
BPRMF (Rendle et al., 2009) 2009 UAI (Anelli et al., 2022, 2023; Mansoury et al., 2022; Sun et al., 2020; Zhao et al., 2022b; Boratto et al., 2022)
ItemkNN (Sarwar et al., 2001) 2001 WWW (Anelli et al., 2022; Boratto et al., 2023a, b, 2022)
NeuMF (He et al., 2017) 2017 WWW (Anelli et al., 2022; Boratto et al., 2023a, b; Mansoury et al., 2022; Sun et al., 2020; Boratto et al., 2022)
LightGCN (He et al., 2020) 2020 SIGIR (Anelli et al., 2023; Boratto et al., 2023a; Zhao et al., 2022b)
UltraGCN (Mao et al., 2021) 2021 CIKM (Anelli et al., 2023)
XSimGCL (Yu et al., 2024) 2024 TKDE ✗
EASE (Steck, 2019) 2019 WWW (Anelli et al., 2022)
MultiVAE (Liang et al., 2018) 2018 WWW (Anelli et al., 2022; Togashi et al., 2024)
RecVAE (Shenbin et al., 2020) 2020 WSDM ✗
DiffRec (Wang et al., 2023) 2023 SIGIR ✗
L-DiffRec (Wang et al., 2023) 2023 SIGIR ✗

S3.T2.caption: Table 2. Recommendation datasets along with their statistics and information about users’ groups and attributes.
S3.T2.table:
Datasets ML1M (Harper and Konstan, 2016) FTKY (Yang et al., 2016)
# Users 6,040 7,240
# Items 3,650 5,779
# Interactions 1,000,130 353,769
Sparsity 95.46% 99.15%
Gender Repr. M : 71.7%; F : 28.3% M : 87.9%; F : 12.1%
Min. Interactions 20 20
references: We assess the performance of the selected baselines on MovieLens-1M (ML1M) (Harper and Konstan, 2016) and Foursquare Tokyo ( (Harper and Konstan, 2016) and Foursquare Tokyo (FTKY) (Yang et al., 2016), which are frequently adopted in fairness-aware literature in recommendation  (Yang et al., 2016), which are frequently adopted in fairness-aware literature in recommendation (Vassøy and Langseth, 2024; Boratto et al., 2023a; Liu et al., 2021). While ML1M is a popular recommendation dataset that collects movies and users’ preferences on them, FTKY involves interactions represented by users’ check-ins at points of interest in Tokyo. In both datasets, users’ sensitive information comes in a binary gender label. Thus, fairness analyses on the consumer side adopt the gender attribute included in both datasets, whereas provider fairness is assessed on a binary partition of the items’ set, namely (Vassøy and Langseth, 2024; Boratto et al., 2023a; Liu et al., 2021). While ML1M is a popular recommendation dataset that collects movies and users’ preferences on them, FTKY involves interactions represented by users’ check-ins at points of interest in Tokyo. In both datasets, users’ sensitive information comes in a binary gender label. Thus, fairness analyses on the consumer side adopt the gender attribute included in both datasets, whereas provider fairness is assessed on a binary partition of the items’ set, namely short-head (popular) and long-tail (niche) items. Following (Boratto et al., 2024; Naghiaei et al., 2022; Mansoury et al., 2022), we select the 20% most popular items as short-head and the rest as long-tail. Dataset statistics are reported in (Boratto et al., 2024; Naghiaei et al., 2022; Mansoury et al., 2022), we select the 20% most popular items as short-head and the rest as long-tail. Dataset statistics are reported in Table 2.
